Union Berlin: Klub yang eksis berkat sumbangan darah pendukungnya
02 Nov 2019, 04:38 by BBC



"Para fans bahkan menyumbangkan darah. Di Jerman, pendonor darah dibayar. Uang yang mereka terima kemudian digunakan untuk menjaga agar klub ini tetap hidup."
Kata-kata yang dilontarkan wartawan sepak bola Jerman, Jacob Sweetman, itu menggambarkan pengorbanan para pendukung Union Berlin dalam perjalanan klub tersebut untuk menggapai momen bersejarah.
Mei lalu, Union Berlin menjadi klub pertama dari Berlin Timur yang mampu berkompetisi di Bundesliga—divisi utama sepak bola Jerman.
Pada Sabtu (02/11) ini, mereka akan berhadapan dengan Hertha Berlin, yang berasal dari bagian barat ibu kota Jerman.
Laga itu terbilang historis karena belum pernah ada pertandingan Bundesliga antara klub dari Berlin Timur dan Berlin Barat. Bahkan, laga ini bisa disebut mustahil jika Tembok Berlin masih membelah kota tersebut.

Pertama kali dalam puluhan tahun, perempuan di Iran bisa menonton sepak bola di stadion


Pria Uni Emirat Arab mencuri 100 miliar dari isteri untuk membeli klub sepak bola Inggris


Setelah Perang Dunia II, Jerman terbagi menjadi dua negara. Jerman Timur dikendalikan Uni Soviet yang komunis, sedangkan Jerman Barat dikuasai Inggris, Prancis, dan Amerika Serikat.
Konsekuensinya, Berlin pun terbagi dua. Pada 1961, sebuah tembok dibangun untuk memisahkan kota sekaligus mencegah warga Berlin Timur yang dikendalikan Soviet kabur ke bagian barat. Tembok itu tidak dirubuhkan sampai 1989.
Meski Jerman telah bersatu sejak 1990, tim-tim dari eks Liga Jerman Timur belum ada yang sanggup berkompetisi di Bundesliga. Union Berlin yang pertama.
'Klub milik para fans'
"Tanpa fans, klub ini tidak ada apa-apanya," kata Sweetman kepada BBC.
Kandang Union adalah Stadion An der Alten Forsterei di kawasan Kopenick. Stadion itu mampu menampung 22.000 penonton.
Pada 2008, klub itu terancam kehilangan lisensinya tatkala tribun-tribun penonton lapuk dan berjatuhan. Namun, sebanyak 2.500 pendukung Union turun tangan guna merenovasi stadion. Secara total mereka bekerja selama 140.000 jam.
Menurutnya, para fans yang membangun stadion memakai helm proyek berwarna merah dan saat itu "tiada satupun mata yang kering di sana".
"Mereka membangkitkan klub itu lagi dan membangun sendiri stadion mereka. Anda bisa merasakannya jika pergi ke sana. Stadion itu punya mereka, bukan orang lain," tutur Sweetman.
Dia menambahkan, ada masa-masa ketika Union berada di ambang kebangkrutan.
Akan tetapi, para fans tidak tinggal diam. Mereka menyumbangkan darah dan memberikan uang hasil donor darah ke pihak klub.
Christian Arbeit, kepala komuniasi Union Berlin, mengatakan aksi dengan tajuk 'Berdarah untuk Union' murni dibentuk oleh para pendukung.
"Ini adalah simbol yang sangat kuat dari apa yang orang-orang siap berikan," kata Arbeit.
Kecintaan para fans kepada klub sedemikian kuat sehingga, menurut wartawan Rylan James, sekelompok fans pernah menerobos masuk ke dalam stadion untuk saling mengucapkan Selamat Natal. Sejak saat itu, aksi tersebut diulangi setiap tahun sebagai suatu tradisi.
"Mereka sangat muak klub kalah pada pertandingan terakhir sebelum Natal sehingga mereka pulang dan bersedih," kata James.
"Mereka kemudian sadar, mereka belum mengucapkan Selamat Natal kepada satu sama lain. Jadi, mereka menerobos ke dalam stadion dengan minuman anggur dan biskuit seraya menyanyikan Selamat Natal serta bernyanyi lagu-lagu Natal di garis tengah lapangan," paparnya.
'Emosi cadas—begitulah Union'


Peragaan ini diciptakan para fans Union sebelum pertandingan Bundesliga menghadapi Borussia Dortmund pada akhir Agustus.

Saat Union bertanding di kandang, tidak ada hiburan saat jeda, iklan, atau musik. Arbeit mengatakan pihak klub tidak perlu "memberikan para fans bantuan untuk merayakan".
"Jika tim kami mencetak gol, ada ledakan keriuhan dan emosi di dalam stadion," katanya.
"Presiden klub melintasi lapangan parkir sebagai fans biasa. Kami erat bersama. Oarng-orang tahu mereka disambut dengan apa yang mereka bawa—gagasan, karya tangan sendiri. Mereka tahu klub mengapresiasinya," imbuh Arbeit.
Seorang pendukung bernama Ingo Petz berkata: "Saya pergi ke Union karena ini adalah klub proletar. Orang-orang suka minum bir. Ada koneksi kuat antara pengendara motor dan orang-orang kenal satu sama lain.
"Emosi cadas ini, begitulah Union. Sepak bola adalah tempat terakhir kami bisa menikmati semua emosi ini dan Union merupakan sebuah tempat yang mempersilakan kami mendukung tim dengan sikap kreatif dan gaduh."
"Orang-orang di tengah masyarakat mencari tempat di mana mereka dihargai—bukan sebagai konsumen tapi sebagai manusia."
'Tembok harus runtuh' dan cerita pemberontakan lain
Nama Union Berlin disematkan pada 1966. Sekitar 60 tahun sebelumnya, klub tersebut memakai beragam nama.
Terlepas dari namanya, menurut Sweetman, klub tersebut senantiasa mengusung identitas "anti-penguasa".
Ada banyak kisah para pendukung klub meneriakkan 'tembok harus runtuh' saat tendangan bebas, karena hanya pada momen tersebut teriakan semacam itu diperbolehkan di Jerman Timur.
"Mereka adalah klub yang mewakili kaum mereka saat Perang Dingin. Berlin adalah kotanya para pemberontak. Anda akan kesulitan menemukan klu yang tidak mewakili pemberontak," kata Sweetman.
Arbeit mengaku sikap "memberontak" tersebut melahirkan "budaya alternative" yang masih eksis di dalam klub hingga sekarang.
"Orang-orang berambut gondrong, berjanggut, dan sebagainya—mereka pergi ke Union dan merasakan kebebasan serta keliaran," terang Arbeit.
"Tidak ada sikap oposisi politik secara gamblang, tapi jika Anda adalah anak muda yang ingin merasakan kebebasan dan menikmati hidup, Anda akan mendukung Union.
"Selama mereka bebas melakukan yang mereka inginkan, mereka merasa hidup. Union menjadi rumah bagi mereka."
Berada di Bundesliga


Para pendukung mengusung hampir 500 poster foto rekan-rekan mereka yang sudah meninggal dunia saat laga debut Bundesliga.

Saat menjalani laga debut Bundesliga di kandang—kalah 4-0 dari RB Leipzig—para pendukung mengusung hampir 500 poster foto rekan-rekan mereka yang sudah meninggal dunia.
"Poster yang mewakili orang-orang yang tidak bisa berada di sini, menggambarkan klub ini dalam berbagai wujud," kata Sweetman.
Petz menambahkan: "Suasananya sangat emosional. Kami membawa teman dan anggota keluarga kami yang meninggal ke dalam stadion. Sangat menghormati mereka."
Hari ketika mereka dipastikan menembus Bundesliga juga emosional dan Arbeit mengaku dirinya "tidak tahu kapan perasaan itu akan berhenti".
"Jika saya menyaksikan foto-foto itu, saya langsung menangis. Begitu menakjubkan bisa melihat kekuatan sepak bola pada masa-masa sekarang, saat seorang pendukung mengalami kesuksesan yang paling tidak bisa dipercaya.
"Para fans tahu tahun ini akan sangat sulit di Bundesliga. Kami harus berjuang sampai pertandingan terakhir untuk tetap berkiprah."

Union Berlin: Club that exists thanks to the blood donation of supporters
02 Nov 2019, 04:38 by BBC



"Fans even donate blood. In Germany, blood donors are paid. The money they receive is then used to keep this club alive."
The words uttered by German football journalist Jacob Sweetman illustrate the sacrifice of Union Berlin supporters on the club's journey to reach a historic moment.
Last May, Union Berlin became the first club from East Berlin to be able to compete in the Bundesliga - the main division of German football.
On Saturday (02/11), they will face Hertha Berlin, who is from the western part of the German capital.
The game was somewhat historical because there had never been a Bundesliga match between clubs from East Berlin and West Berlin. In fact, this fight can be called impossible if the Berlin Wall still divides the city.

After World War II, Germany was divided into two countries. East Germany was controlled by the communist Soviet Union, while West Germany was controlled by Britain, France and the United States.
Consequently, Berlin was divided in two. In 1961, a wall was built to separate the city while preventing Soviet-controlled East Berliners from fleeing to the west. The wall was not demolished until 1989.
Although Germany has been united since 1990, no teams from the former East German League have been able to compete in the Bundesliga. The first Berlin Union.
'The club belongs to the fans'
"Without fans, this club is nothing," Sweetman told the BBC.
Coop Union is the An der Alten Forsterei Stadium in the Kopenick area. The stadium can accommodate 22,000 spectators.
In 2008, the club threatened to lose its license when the stands were obsolete and fell. However, as many as 2,500 Union supporters intervened to renovate the stadium. In total they worked 140,000 hours.
According to him, the fans who built the stadium wore red project helmets and at that time "not a single dry eye was there".
"They revived the club again and built their own stadium. You can feel it if you go there. The stadium is theirs, not someone else," said Sweetman.
He added, there were times when the Union was on the verge of bankruptcy.
However, the fans did not stay silent. They donate blood and give money from blood donations to the club.
Christian Arbeit, head of Union Berlin's communication, said the action with the headline "Bloody for the Union" was formed purely by supporters.
"This is a very strong symbol of what people are ready to give," Arbeit said.
The fans' love for the club was so strong that, according to journalist Rylan James, a group of fans had burst into the stadium to wish each other a Merry Christmas. Since then, the action is repeated every year as a tradition.
"They were very fed up with the club losing the last game before Christmas so they went home and were sad," James said.
"They then realized, they have not wished Merry Christmas to each other. So, they broke into the stadium with wine and biscuits while singing Merry Christmas and singing Christmas songs in the middle of the field," he explained.
'Rock emotion - that's the Union'


This demonstration was created by Union fans before the Bundesliga match against Borussia Dortmund at the end of August.

When the Union competes at home, there is no entertainment during breaks, advertisements, or music. Arbeit said the club did not need to "give fans help to celebrate".
"If our team scores a goal, there is an explosion of hubbub and emotions inside the stadium," he said.
"The club president crossed the parking lot as an ordinary fan. We are closely together. People know they are welcomed by what they bring - ideas, the work of their own hands. They know the club appreciates it," added Arbeit.
A supporter named Ingo Petz said: "I went to Union because this is a proletarian club. People like to drink beer. There is a strong connection between motorcyclists and people who know each other.
"This rock emotion is Union. Football is the last place we can enjoy all these emotions and Union is a place that allows us to support the team with a creative and rowdy attitude."
"People in the community are looking for a place where they are valued — not as consumers but as humans."
'The wall must collapse' and other stories of rebellion
The name Union Berlin was pinned in 1966. About 60 years earlier, the club used various names.
Regardless of its name, according to Sweetman, the club always carries an "anti-ruler" identity.
There are many stories of supporters of the club shouting 'the wall must collapse' during a free kick, because only at that moment such screaming is allowed in East Germany.
"They are a club that represents their people during the Cold War. Berlin is the city of the rebels. You will find it difficult to find those who do not represent the rebels," Sweetman said.
Arbeit claimed that the "rebellious" attitude gave birth to an "alternative culture" that still exists in the club today.
"Long-haired people, beards and so on — they go to the Union and experience freedom and wildness," explained Arbeit.
"There is no obvious political opposition, but if you are a young person who wants to experience freedom and enjoy life, you will support the Union.
"As long as they are free to do what they want, they feel alive. Union is home to them."
Located in the Bundesliga


Supporters carried nearly 500 photo posters of their colleagues who had died during the Bundesliga debut match.

When undergoing the Bundesliga debut match at home - losing 4-0 to RB Leipzig - supporters carried nearly 500 photo posters of their deceased colleagues.
"Posters representing people who can't be here, portray this club in various forms," Sweetman said.
Petz added: "The atmosphere was very emotional. We brought our friends and family members who died into the stadium. Respectfully honored them."
The day they were confirmed to have broken into the Bundesliga was also emotional and Arbeit claimed he "didn't know when those feelings would stop".
"If I watch those photos, I immediately cry. It's amazing to see the power of football in the present, when a supporter experiences the most unbelievable success.
"The fans know this year will be very difficult in the Bundesliga. We have to fight until the last match to keep up."
